characters: IF YOU WILL NOT JOIN US WILLINGLY,
HUMANS, YOU LEAVE US NO RECOURSE.
WE WILL BE FORCED TO USE OTHER
YOU NEED TO EXPLAIN THIS NOW
HUMANS, YOU LEAVE US NO RECOURSE...

dialogues.speaker: INT./EXT. 1990
dialogues.text: Over corridors, school children and falling A4 paper. images match the narration, warm with nostalgia.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was June 22nd 1990, our final day of school. There were five of us. Oliver Chamberlain, Peter Page, Steven Prince, Andy Knightley and me. They called me The King. Because my name's Gary King. The We see a teenage GARY, the school cool cat with trendy ha black trench coat and irrepressible grin.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Me and the boys, we were inseparable: Ollie was funny, he fancied himself as a bit of a player but really, he was all mouth. We called him O-Man because he had a birthmark that looked like a six. He loved it. We see a teenage OLIVER, a yuppie in training, with city accessories and a brick of a mobile phone. The boys try t distract him. He gives them the finger, mouths "Fuck off"

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Pete was the baby of the group. We sort of took him under our wing. Pete wasn't the kind of kid we'd usually hang out with but he was good for a laugh and his dad was minted. Diminutive PETER gets nudged in the corridor by a BURLY K In Peter's garden, Gary cannonballs into a swimming pool, soaking an older man who is apparently Peter's dad.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Steve was a cool guy, almost as cool as me. We jammed together, formed a band, we chased the girls. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I think he kinda saw us as rivals. Sweet really. Young STEVEN is handsome. We see him smoking with Gary an jamming on guitars in the music room. Gary and Steven wat the same PRETTY GIRL walk past them.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And Andy? Well what can I say? Andy was my wing man. The one guy I could rely on to back me up. I loved him and I'm not being funny, he loved me too.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There were a few people we'd miss. Mr. Shepherd was cool. I remember one time, he asked what I wanted to do with my life. MR. SHEPHERD sits across from Gary in a careers office.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I told him I just want to have a good time. He thought that was funny. It wasn't meant to be. We see their home town from above: A nondescript garden c set out in symmetrical circles of grey and green.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Newton Haven was our hometown. Our cradle, our playground, our universe and that night it was the site of an heroic quest. The aim? To conquer The Golden Mile. Twelve pubs along a legendary path of alcoholic indulgence, terminating at the alehouse that would herald our success: The World's End. The aerial view merges into a TOURIST MAP of Newton Haven The boys crowd around it, charting the route with blue markers.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There was The First Post, The Old Familiar, The Famous Cock, The Cross Hands, The Good Companions, The Trusty Servant, The Two Headed Dog, The Mermaid, The Beehive, The King's Head, The Hole in the Wall... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old-fashioned pub signs flash past like tarot cards.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...all before reaching our destiny. The World's End appears, the most important pub of all.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We took my car into town, I called it The Beast because she was pretty hairy. Gary drives a MATT BLACK GRANADA MK2 dangerously fast.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And so, our attempt at The Golden Mile began. We were off. We didn’t waste any time. We hit pub one and we hit it hard. They enter The First Post. The boys sit at a table and al down their pints together.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Things got crazy fast. There was drinking, there was fun... The boys down pint after pint in successive pubs. Steven chats with a GRIZZLED OLD DRINKER. The others laugh.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...there was controversy... A publican holds a red card up to Gary, who protests.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...there were ladies... They flirt with THREE ALLURING SCHOOLGIRLS, two with blon hair, one with red.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...there was drama, and of course... Gary in a pub toilet punching the wall in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...there was drinking. The boys raise a toast together in The Good Companions. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: After pub five we were feeling invincible and decided to procure some herbal refreshment from a man we knew as The Reverend Green. The boys buy hash from a SHIFTY LOOKING DEALER. Oliver, t drunk to carry on, throws up and waves them away.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Pint six put O-Man out of action, so we carried on without him. Good thing, I bumped into his little sister in the next pub, we went into the disabled toilets and I bumped into her again. We see Gary with the same pretty girl he and Steven check out earlier. Gary winks at a jealous Steven.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Sam tagged along for a while but in the end I had to let her go. I told her I had another date that night and her name was Amber. The boys clash pints. The boys have reached The Beehive.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Nine pints in and it was us against the world; least it felt like it. Drinks are spilt, a brawl starts. Andy is in the center.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: After the Beehive, we had to lay low and so we repaired to the bowls club or as we liked to call it: The Smokehouse. And that’s when it all went fuck up. The boys approach a BOWLING GREEN CLUBHOUSE to smoke pot.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Everyone got para and Pete chucked a whitey so we had to bench him. We see them leave a comatose Peter on a park bench.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: In the end, we blew off the last three pubs and headed for the hills. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary, Andy and Steven stagger along a dark street.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We thought about taking The Beast but eventually decided against it. The Beast crashes into a low wall, steam rising.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Don’t know how we got up there in the end. Maybe Lady Luck was with us after all. Gary, Andy and Steven sit on a hilltop and look out acros Newton Haven. A SHOOTING STAR streaks across the sky. And puts an arm round Gary. It is the beautiful idyll of yout

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I remember sitting up on top of that hill, blood on my knuckles, beer down my shirt, sick on my shoes, seeing the orange glow of a new dawn break and knowing in my heart, life would never feel this good again. And you know what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Gary King, age 40. Lines of experience etched acro his face, but with the same broad smile.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: It never did. A strangely self-satisfied Gary leans back in his chair. still thin, drawn even, with dyed black hair. Gary is among a group of people, sitting in a circle. A bemused silence settles as the people regard Gary and eac other. We hear the WELL SPOKEN VOICE of a male GROUP LEAD

dialogues.speaker: GROUP LEADER
dialogues.text: Thank you Gary. That was very enlightening. Would anyone like to add anything or maybe challenge Gary?

dialogues.speaker: PALE YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Are you disappointed?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: About what? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PALE YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: That you didn't make it to The World's End? Close on Gary. Yes. Yes. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: No. Gary zones out. We hear the following movie dialogue.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Just what is it that you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: PETER FONDA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We want to be free! We want to be free to do what we want to do! And we want to get loaded. And we want to have a good time. And that's what we're going to do. We're going to have a good time. We're going to have a party. TITLE CARD - ‘THE WORLD’S END’ MONTAGE. VARIOUS SUBURBAN DOMESTIC & WORKPLACE LOCATIONS. Primal Scream’s ‘Loaded’ plays over a montage of domestic We see present day versions of the adult PETER, OLIVER, STEVEN and ANDY getting ready for work. PETER, older, still slight, sitting at the breakfast tabl He checks his watch, drinks his coffee and reads the pape amid the pandemonium of a family breakfast. STEVEN, older, well preserved. He is in sweats, working o with an attractive young female fitness instructor. OLIVER, in a slick business suit, in line at a coffee sho talks loudly on his bluetooth headset and annoys others. ANDY, still robust, but with an air of executive power, s into a fancy elevator, briefcase in hand. EXT. PETER’S HOUSE - MORNING A garage door opens. We see Peter at the wheel of a midpr family car. As he pulls out of the garage he sees- Gary, back in his 1990 trench coat. Standing in the stree (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Peter can take this in, Gary drops down behind a hedge. Peter pulls out from his drive and finds no one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter sits behind his desk. On the shopfloor he sees a ma perusing a shiny new model. He puts on his sales face.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: She’s a beauty.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Oh yes but she’s no Beast. Hello Peter. Peter jumps like he’s seen a ghost.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Jesus! Gary?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: The once and future King.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Were you outside my house this morning?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I could have sworn I saw you on my street earlier.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I've never been to Bishop's Gardens. Gary changes the subject with a friendly punch in the arm

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: How you doing man?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'm good. You?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Never better. How is-

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Vanessa? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: No, no, no. Your wife?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Vanessa.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yeah. How’s she?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: She’s good.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Have you had sex yet?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: We have two children.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Ooh twice. Get you, fuck machine. (laughs at own joke) We haven’t changed have we? An older, very concerned salesman approaches.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: What is he doing here?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It's alright, Dad. We're fine.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Hello Mr. P. Peter's dad glares at Gary and stalks off.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: He looks well.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: So what can I do for you Gary? Are you looking to buy a car?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: No Peter. The End Is Nigh.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: The World's End. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You know what I mean. One night. Five guys. Twelve pubs. Let battle commence.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You want to try that again?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Isn't that something you've always wanted?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Not really, no.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Pete, we didn't make it before but this time, we'll see it through to the bitter end. Or lager end.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: We?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yeah, the whole gang.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Even Andy?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Why wouldn't Andy be coming?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I thought that after the accident-

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Not an issue. He's in. Are you?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'd have to check with Vanessa.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Who's Vanessa?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: My wife.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Since when do you have to check with your wife? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Since we got married?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Come on, don't you miss it? The laughter, the camaraderie, the fights, the hangovers so fierce it feels like your head is full of ants.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Maybe the first two.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: It begins. What's your new number?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Same one I've had for ten years.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yeah. What's that one? Peter reluctantly gives Gary his card.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: So you and Andy are all straight?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Can I ask you a favour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modern building is under construction. Inside is Steven now an architect, looking at plans with his head builder. He’s smart casual, with hard hat and hi-vis vest.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD BUILDER
dialogues.text: Who’s the helmet without the helmet?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: That’s Gary King. A hard-hatless Gary strolls blithely into the path of a l digger which comes to a sudden stop, showering the ground with rubble. Gary saunters on, oblivious. In answer, Stev shakes his head forlornly. Gary taps on the door frame.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Knock knock. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What are you doing here, Gary?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You’re supposed to say who’s there.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I can see who’s there.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I like what you’ve done with the place. Bit draughty. How’s Selina?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: We divorced ten years ago.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I wondered how she was.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: She’s very well... apparently.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You got anyone on the go?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I have as it happens. She's a fitness instructor. Twenty-six.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Paedo. I'm kidding. I'd love to meet her sometime.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: No. Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Haven't you heard? We're getting the band back together.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I'm not your bass player anymore.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: No I meant I'm getting the boys back together. We can get the band back together as well if you like.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: No we can't Gary. You sold my guitar to buy drugs. Gary changes the subject at lightning speed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I've always wondered, what's that thing above the door called?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: A lintel.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: So, plan is, we're going back to Newton Haven, to do The Golden Mile and this time, we're going to get to The World's End. Everyone's in.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What, even Andy?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You better believe it big balls.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Andy is going drinking? With you?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: With us. Think about it, go back to the old town, sink a few pints-

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Twelve pints.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Twelve pints is insane.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I know!

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What is this all about, Gary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary is lying on a sofa with his feet up.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: It's about closure. Why should getting older affect something as important as friendship? A lot's changed since then Oliver. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gary talks to the older Oliver, dressed in a business sui holds a clipboard. He stares back at Gary.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: For some of us, yes.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: This is a chance to take stock.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: A stock take? You make it sound so much fun.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Come on O-Man. Isn't that something you'd like?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: What I'd really like is for you to take your DMs off that sofa.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Listen, if you're worried about me, don't be. I'm here to tell you, Gary King is back on the horse.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: You're back on the horse?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I mean I'm back on the bike.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: What is bike?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: What is bike slang for?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Bicycle?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I’m lost.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Don’t be.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Oh, alright then. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Look, this is our chance to finally finish what we started. C’mon man, it’ll be fucking mental!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG LADY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Um... I think we’re all done. We see a YOUNG COUPLE. They may have been here for a whil Oliver suddenly switches into estate agent mode. The young

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: How do you like the property?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG LADY
dialogues.text: It’s really lovely. It’s just-

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: It’s a little bit out of our price range.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: He’1l knock some off. How much is it?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: One point two million.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Fuck me. Run! couple leave. Oliver turns to Gary. Not happy.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Gary, W.T.F.?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: It’s good to see you too O-Man.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Gary, please don’t call me O-Man.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Sure. Hey, how's your sister?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: She's fine.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Does she ever talk about me?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: No. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: So, Friday, we'll go down together. Make a road trip of it, I'll drive.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Don't think I can. I'm pretty sure I have a doctor's appointment.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yeah you do. With Dr. Ink! Y'know, Dr. Ink? D-R-I

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yes 'Drink' I get it.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You gotta come. It wouldn't be the same without the O-Man.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Look, you can see the guys, see how they're doing. Tell them how you're doing. Hey, you never know, you might make it to the end this time.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: And Andy's definitely going?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Andy Knightley?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Totes.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: And you convinced him, how?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brushed Knightley steel nameplate reads 'Beckingham, Davies & LLB'. A secretary pushes through a glass door where we find Andy behind a desk in an impressive office space.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Mr. Knightley. You have a friend to see you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gary can be seen in the lobby, popping the top off an asp bottle and necking a mouthful of pills. Andy's face falls

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: No, I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stern Andy observes Gary swiveling in a chair.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: This is a bit grown up isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Saw the guys the other day.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Did you?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: O-Man, Stevie-Baby, the Petertron.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Yes, I remember the names of our childhood friends.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: We had ourselves a little idea. We're going back. To Newton Haven-

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: That's a joke, right?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Five guys. Twelve pubs. Fifty pints.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Sixty.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Steady on, you fucking alky.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I haven’t had a drink for sixteen years. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You must be thirsty then. (off Andy’s glare) Come on, we can catch up, chew the fat, it'll be just like it always was, except this time we’re going to finish it once and for all.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: You have a very selective memory, Gary.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: You remember the Friday nights. I remember the Monday mornings.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: That’s why we’re going back on a Friday.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Gary, why do you think none of us live in Newton Haven anymore? Because it’s a black hole. It’s boring and it always was and it always will be.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: It’s only boring because we’re not there.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It’s pointless arguing with you.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Exactly. So come. I’m picking everyone up from High Wycombe station, Friday, 3 o’clock sharp.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: No, Gary.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me, you have to check with the missus?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: No, actually, I don’t have to check with the missus. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy stands up. Points to the door. Gary nods,

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Showing you the door.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Is that a door? It doesn't have a lintel. And it's glass. So is ita window or is it a door? I guess it's a windoor. You can have that.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Please leave Gary. stands and puts an envelope on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Six hundred wasn't it? Oh, by the way...

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Thought you should know. Mum died.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Few weeks ago. The Big... Cancer.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: With Mum dying, I've been thinking about the old days. About that night. I love the boys like brothers, Andy, but when all's said and done, you're the best friend I ever had. It was good to see you, mate. Gary extends a hand to say goodbye. Andy looks at it.  19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A train pulls up. Peter cautiously steps onto the platfor Steven appears from the next carriage and walks over.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Peter?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Thank god. I had a horrible feeling I was going to be the only one here.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I reckon that’s not the last horrible feeling you’ll have today.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: This can't be happening. Can it?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You said it, mate. They share warm if awkward hugs and pleasantries.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What the hell are we doing?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What we always did. Oliver approaches, a mini-suitcase trailing behind him.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Follow Gary King into almost certain oblivion. Peter and Steven greet Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Didn't we decide to stop calling him fearless leader somewhere around 1992?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Old habits die hard.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: We'll be putting that on Gary's tombstone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: No we won't. Gary's going to outlive us all.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: That'd be funny if it wasn't true. Peter notices Oliver looking quizzically at him and Steve

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to figure out which of us is the biggest idiot for coming. A whistle. They turn to see Andy standing on the next platform. He wears the resigned look of a condemned man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The station clock reads '3.57'. Andy, Oliver, Steven and Peter sit on their bags. They check their watches.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Maybe he’s had an accident. Sorry Andy.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It’s fine. Gary having an accident would actually be the best outcome for us all. Including Gary. THE BEAST comes tearing in. Matt black. Belching fumes. 'There's No Other Way' by Blur blaring from the stereo. G parks and bounds over to the others, excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Oh yes! Look at these cunts.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: You're late.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: No I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It's almost 4, you said 3.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yeah, 3 for 4. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: You know your problem Gary? You're never wrong.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: How is that a problem? Gary throws the bags into the boot of The Beast.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I can't believe you bought another Granada MK2.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: This looks exactly like the car I sold you in 1989.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: This is the car you sold me in 1989. Best 300 quid I ever spent.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: This is The Beast?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Pretty much. She's had a bit of work done. New suspension, brakes, exhaust, seats, wheels, panelling, carburettor, manifold - well, the whole engine really - other than that, it's the same old motor.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: One might say an antique.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Then what say we get this antique on the roadshow? The clock chimes four times. Gary beams, oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Cc’mon you bellends. We’re going to be late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gang sit cramped in the car. Gary tries to start it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: And we’re back. The Five Musketeers.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Three Musketeers isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Four if you count D’Artagnan.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Well nobody really knows how many there were do they? History’s a sketchbook.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: You know Three Musketeers is a fiction? Written by Alexandre Dumas?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Well, a lot of people are saying that about the Bible now.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: That it was written by Alexandre Dumas?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Don’t be daft, it was written by Jesus. Anyway, five sounds better. They missed a trick only having three. Two of them could’ve died and you'd still have three left.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Are we there yet? The engine finally roars to life. Gary hits the gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Beast roars along the M-Whatever. 'I'm Free' by The S Dragons blasts from the stereo. Gary sings along.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Soup Dragons! Haven't heard this in years. I put this on a tape for you didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yeah. This is it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: This is the tape?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Where did you find it?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: In the tape player. We see a sign saying 'SERVICES'.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Anyone hungry? They pass the safest point to exit for 'SERVICES',

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I need a piss actually. 23. but then- SCREECH. Gary swerves off the motorway at a hairy speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others wait around. The atmosphere is stilted.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: This is a long piss.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: If it is a piss. Might be a little- (Mimes snorting line)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Poo?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: How is that a poo?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Still work for your old man, Pete?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'm a partner now. How about you?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, started my own firm in '98. Got bought out in '05. I'm happier though. It's less stress. Olly? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Property. I co-manage a little boutique estate agency in North London. Oliver produces a number of business cards and hands them Andy, Peter and Steven who pocket them out of politeness.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Very competitive.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Is it family law you're in, Andy?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Corporate.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Does anyone know what Gary's doing?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: He's playing 'Need For Speed'. Over there. Andy points towards an amusement arcade where Gary is enthusiastically playing a driving game.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He hasn't changed has he?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I don't know. He did finally pay me back that £600.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Oh really? He borrowed 200 from me.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: And me. They all look at Peter. He sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gang are back on the road. Andy is furious.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you'd do that! What am I saying? Of course I can. It’s just robbing Peter to pay Paul. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I borrowed it from Peter to pay you. I still owe Paul. Andy glares at Gary. He is oblivious to their scorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Step On' by The Happy Mondays blares as The Beast roars downhill past the ‘Welcome to Newton Haven’ sign.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Oh shit. Newton Haven. We see a nondescript sprawl in the valley below.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Take a moment to look upon it in its original colours boys, for tonight we paint it red. The Beast roars past a MOTORCYCLE COP. Immediately- POLIC SIRENS WHOOP. The Motorcycle Cop pulls them over.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Fuck-fuck-fuck-fuck-fuck-fuck. Gary pats his pockets madly. The others look horrified.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Oh no, wait, it's alright. I did it all at the services. KNOCK KNOCK. The Motorcycle Cop taps on the driver's wind Gary winds it down and turns off the stereo.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLE COP
dialogues.text: Know why I pulled you over, sir?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Music too loud?

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLE COP
dialogues.text: Your left brake light is faulty.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Argh. The old brake lights! So called because they break all the time. I’1l get it sorted officer.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLE COP
dialogues.text: Can I see your license, sir? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yes. No. Wait. It’s in my wallet. And I left that in the bloody gym!

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLE COP
dialogues.text: Any other form of identification?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: No, it’s all in my sports bag. Typical. I’1l happily give you my name and address if you need to run me through the old system.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLE COP
dialogues.text: Go on then.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: It’s Peter Page. And it’s 48 Bishop’s Gardens, London, N2 112. The Cop returns to his bike. The others furiously whisper

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Jesus, Gary! W.T.F.?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Why did you give him my name?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I’m not giving him my name am I?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What if I get done by the police?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You won’t get done by the police.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Gary, he’ll check the number-plate against his name! The Motorcycle Cop returns. They all shut up.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLE COP
dialogues.text: So Mr. Page, what brings you to Newton Haven?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: We're all from here. Back to see the sights. Have a crack at The Golden Mile. Might get messy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLE COP
dialogues.text: Well, make sure you get that brake light fixed, Peter and don't make too much mess.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: We won't! Gary drives off. Stunned silence.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I - I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: It's simple, Pete. The car's still registered to you, has been since "89.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: But I've moved house three times since then.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I know, I changed the log book, I've done this loads of times. Where do you think all those points came from? Seriously. You guys need to relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Beast is parked outside a modest Bed and Breakfast. Steven, Oliver and Peter walk towards the entrance with t bags. Andy, still fuming, retrieves his belongings.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Do you know how much trouble you could get into?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Do you know how much trouble I'm in?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: What's that supposed to mean? What the hell is this, Gary? Why are we even here?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: We are here to get annihilated.  28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A kindly landlady watches as the boys fill in forms.

dialogues.speaker: LANDLADY
dialogues.text: Do you have plans for dinner? Gary takes a TOURIST MAP from a display, opens it out.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Tonight, we will be partaking of a liquid repast as we wend our way up The Golden Mile, commencing with an inaugural tankard at The First Post then onto The Old Familiar, The Famous Cock, The Cross Hands, The Good Companions, The Trusty Servant, The Two Headed Dog, The Mermaid, The Beehive, The King’s Head and The Hole in the Wall for a measure of the same, all before that last bitter sweet pint in that most fateful terminus, The World’s End. Leave a light on good lady, for though we may return with a twinkle in our eyes, we will, in truth be blind... drunk. The landlady stares at Gary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy sits on his bed. We hear banging from another room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven flicks through the TV channels. More banging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver is laying out some clothes onto the bed.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter frowns at the noises coming from Gary’s room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Fuck it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All four peer out of their rooms. Gary emerges livid.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: No mini-bar!

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Aren't we just about to drink twelve pints of beer?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Fuck me, he's keen. Let's boo-boo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'So Young' by Suede plays as the group swagger along in slowmo. VARIOUS PASSERSBY regard them with mild indiffere Newton Haven in all its underwhelming glory: Floral displ ring roads, neat avenues. They walk past FIVE TEENAGE BOY and see a reflection of their former selves. Gary nods to them, as if they have something in common. Gary rings someone's doorbell and runs off, forcing the others to do the same. Gary laughs, they don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary poised, one foot up on a picnic table like a tour gu

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Until 1840-

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: For fuck's sake.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: -this building was the site of Newton Haven's first Post Office. Then an enterprising business fellow decided that, far from benefitting matters of the sending and receiving of mail, it was better suited as a humble tap-room where one could get twatted. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gary nods sagely and opens the door with a flourish to-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -the shittiest chain pub you’ve ever seen. It’s completel without charm or atmosphere. Gary smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: It’s like déja vu.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I don't remember this at all. Has it been refurbished?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Must have been bought by a chain.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yes, it's part of that nationwide initiative to rob small, charming pubs of any discernible character.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Starbucking, man. It's happening everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Can't take away that smell though.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I'm sure they tried. They walk to the bar. There are few patrons present. Gary approaches PUBLICAN 1 with an expectant smile.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Good evening Raymondo. The prodigal sons return. The publican doesn't seem to recognise Gary.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Who's on the guest list tonight?

dialogues.speaker: PUBLICAN 1
dialogues.text: Come again?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: The guest ales. We're doing The Golden Mile and you sir, have the honour of drawing first blood. What do you recommend? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PUBLICAN 1
dialogues.text: There's one. Crowning Glory.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Rather fitting.

dialogues.speaker: PUBLICAN 1
dialogues.text: Why's that?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I'm Gary King.

dialogues.speaker: PUBLICAN 1
dialogues.text: What? Gary continues, not phased.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: So tell me more.

dialogues.speaker: PUBLICAN 1
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Crowning Glory. Is it hoppy? Is it nutty? Is it foamy? Does it have a surprisingly fruity note that lingers on the tongue?

dialogues.speaker: PUBLICAN 1
dialogues.text: It's beer.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Mmmmmm, we'll have five of those then.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Four. And one tap water.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You fucking what?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group sits at the same table from the prologue. 31. Gary looks at Andy sipping his water and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I can't believe this, a man of your legendary prowess drinking fucking rain. It's like seeing a lion eating some hummus. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: That doesn't make any sense.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I know it doesn't make any sense.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: You seriously have a problem with me not drinking, after what happened?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I don't but King Arthur does!

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Ooh this'll be good.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: What's King Arthur got to with it?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Do you think King Arthur would have come back from the Battle Of Hastings, fucking rocked up at Arthur’s Castle-

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Camelot.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: - gone to the bar and ordered a tap water?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: No, because they wouldn’t have had running water in Arthurian times.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Exactly. He would have ordered a mead. The King Arthur of beers.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Mead’s a honey wine isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: And I’m less of a man because I choose to drink water?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: It’s a bit ‘ooh ducky’ innit?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That’s not very PC, Gary. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Get out of the nineties mate.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Listen there’s nothing ‘ooh ducky’ about being teetotal, about walking into a pub after a rubgy match and ordering a tap water at a bar packed with big ugly bastards wearing war paint. That Gary, takes confidence. I’m talking balls.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You said it, poof.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I don’t know if you've noticed this but we are not teenagers anymore. I mean, god forbid you ever have children, because if-

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I might have kids.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Then you had better be ready to take responsibilty-

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: No. I mean I might have kids. Andy and the others look lost.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Remember Karen Eggerton who I... (euphemistic gesture) ... fucked? She was two weeks late when her family emigrated to Normandy. Never heard from her again. She might have had a baby. Imagine that? A French kid.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It's pointless arguing with you.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: To kids. Wherever they may be. Gary toasts and drains his Bud.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Come on. Let's boo-boo. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: "Boo-boo". What is that?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You remember? "Let's boo-boo". On the wall of Mr. Shepherd's classroom, it used to say 'Exit, Pursued By Bear', y'know, from the Shakespeare play?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: ‘A Winter's Tale'.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yeah. What was it called?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: ‘A Winter's Tale'.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: That's it. When we needed to make a quick getaway we'd go 'Exit, Pursued By Bear' then 'Exit, Pursued By Yogi Bear', then 'Let's Yogi and Boo-Boo', then 'Let's Boo- Boo'.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: So you're saying we should go?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s shit here innit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary leads the march to the next watering hole.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Ah. The Old Familiar. Now this is a pub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the second shittiest pub you've ever seen. The is literally no difference between this and the previous

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Now I have déja vu. Gary walks off toward the bar and hails the publican. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: David my man, have you heard the news? Gary King is back in town.

dialogues.speaker: PUBLICAN 2
dialogues.text: Who's he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tick tock. The group sits around the table in SOLEMN SILE

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: How was the funeral, Gary?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Your mum's funeral?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: It's difficult to put into words. But if I had to choose three, I'd say ‘really, really sad'. Wait, that's two. How about 'really, very sad'? Lot of people wearing black. Lot of hats. Like a wedding, but where someone's dead.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It's a shame, she was a good woman. I liked your mum.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Me too. Oliver pipes up loudly and unprompted.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Hello mate.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Are you here?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I’ve been here for ages. Oliver shushes Gary. Indicates he’s on his earpiece.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: You get lost on the ring-road again? This is Newton Haven. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What time are you meeting The Twins? We’re all at The Old Familiar. Come by if you want. Oliver glances at Gary, who’s listening intently.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yeah, he is. Okay. See you soon.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Who was that, O-Man?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Don’t call me O-Man, Gary and if you must know it was Sam.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Sam's here?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Is there a fucking echo? Yes, Sam's here. She’s down from Manchester. We're driving to Mum’s tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: And Sam’s coming here now?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Calm down Steve, I saw her first.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Oh for fuck’s sake, not this.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Are you fucking kidding me? I saw her first. Wow, you really have a selective memory don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Someone else was saying that.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, me.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: No. I would have remembered.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I told you I had a thing about Sam then you proceeded to try and get in her pants at every opportunity. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Guys please-

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You only liked her after you found out I liked her!

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: That's right, you did Cabaret at school because she was in it and she wore those fishnets tights and you got a big old boner on stage.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ-—

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Don't matter anyway, I think she had a massive wide on for Adrian Keane.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I hate that prick.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Can we not talk about my sister in relation to a) massive wide ons and b) Steven's erect penis?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Of course. Is she still fit though?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I'm not going to answer that.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Is she though?

dialogues.speaker: SAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Am I what? SAM enters. She's 38 and yes, she's still-

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Fit. Steven stands up, like a gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Hi Sam.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Steve? You've grown haven't you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yeah, sideways.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You look fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Steroids.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Hi Pete, Andy, wow long time. Alright big brother? She ruffles Oliver's hair. Her smile fades-

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Gary.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Wilkommen. Bienvenue. Welcome.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Sam. Would you like a drink?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Slow down! She's only just here. Gary shakes his head at Steven. Then-

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Sam. Would you like a drink?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Vodka tonic thanks Steven. I'm just going to nip to the loo. She leaves. Gary chuckles then follows her to the toilets

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I'm going to the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Well then, so am I.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Gary! You are out of your mind! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? You gave me the sign.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What sign?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You went to the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Are you serious? I haven't seen you in twenty years and you think I'm going to have sex with you in the ladies' toilet.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Well the disableds' is out of order.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Gary. What happened?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I don't know, maybe one of them put too many paper towels down the toilet. We don't really know what they are thinking.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No. What happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Nothing. Nothing happened to me. I'm the same old Gary.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No shit.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: So, d'you wanna? Sam slaps Gary. Very hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary is back at the table. Sam returns.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Oliver. I'll see you later. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You're going?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I thought you weren’t meeting The Twins for another half hour?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I’m not. Sam puts a sign on the table in front of Gary.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I believe this is yours. Sam exits. Gary picks up the sign. “OUT OF ORDER”.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Out of order. It’s a private joke. Gary laughs it off and pockets the sign.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I don’t want to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys walk to the next pub. They pass an obtrusive BRO SCULPTURE in the centre of the park. It’s a Henry Moore-l humanoid figure but with long jagged limbs.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What the hell is that?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Modern art.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It’s a memorial isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Yeah. To modern art.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Hey, what time is it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Christ, it’s not even six.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Wrong! It's high time we got onto The Cock! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gary runs on ahead to 'The Famous Cock'. The others eye r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Fools Gold' by The Stone Roses is playing. The gang ling at the bar. Gary is trying to get served.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: When you're ready, mate. PUBLICAN 3 serves another customer first.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Oh shit. Look who it is. Gary points to a GRIZZLED OLD DRINKER from the prologue. is at the bar, drinking his lager through a crazy straw.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Basil.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Mad Basil! D'you remember? We used to sit in here for hours and listen to his crazy stories about UFOs and lizard people and underwater Nazis.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Didn't he spout some bullshit about the Bermuda Triangle actually being a square?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: No, he said it was two Isosceles Triangles forming a rhombus.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: He was your best mate wasn't he Steve?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: He wasn't my best mate. He was just a lonely, old man and I felt sorry for him.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: That’s right. (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: BASIL
dialogues.text: BASIL turns around. Gary waves and points at the group. B either doesn’t remember them or chooses not to. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Maybe we're not the local legends you think we are.

dialogues.speaker: PUBLICAN 3, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Gary King?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Speak for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: PUBLICAN 3
dialogues.text: You're barred. The Publican indicates a wall of shame. We see photos of angry drunks. Among them a smiling young Gary, thumbs alo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group leaves, with Gary shouting back through the doo

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: c'mon, this is fucking ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Have two in the next one.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: He can have them all in the next one, for all I care.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: We've got to have one in every pub or the whole thing's fucked.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I'd say it was fairly fucked already. They leave Gary behind. He spots three glasses of lager o picnic table, the sum of the dregs add up to a pint. We h the Stone Roses singing "Foooo000l's Gold".

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: How much more of this do we have to endure?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: That was three. There's nine more.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Oh good. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Fuck this. I need to eat something.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: We could get something in the next pub.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: As long as it’s reasonably healthy.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: This is Newton Haven. Not exactly the heart of the organic revolution.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I doubt it's the heart of anything?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: My wife wanted us to go organic, problem is, I like eating shit. Gary is suddenly back with them and running on ahead.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: The next pub does shit! Keep up! Angle on the picnic table, the three glasses, now empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This pub is much busier and seems friendlier. The gang si sipping their drinks and eating chunky chips.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I remember this one.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: We had New Year's here.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Wasn't that when you fell asleep on the pool table, Andy?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I believe it was.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: For six hours. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They all smile and laugh in recollection. Gary spots the FIVE TEENAGE BOYS at the pool table.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yeah and when you woke up, we told you it was 1991 and you got all freaked out and punched a clock.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That was a great night.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Didn’t you manage to get off with Erica Leekes, Peter?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I did. Something of a personal triumph, if I say so myself.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: She of the Marmalade Sandwich fame?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: The very same.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Erika Leekes, Tracy Benson and Becky Salt. Two blondes and a redhead in the middle.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: The Marmalade Sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: (in reverie) Becky Salt. Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Wonder what they’re doing now.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Why don’t you ask them?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Well sitting at that table over there are two blondes with a redhead in the middle.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sitting with their backs to them are three women: Two wit blonde hair, one with red. We can’t see their faces.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I'd say that’s Erica Leekes on the left, Tracy Benson on the right and by process of elimination, Becky Salt in the middle. The Marmalade Sandwich. All growed up.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That is very spooky.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Let's get them over. Gary stands to go over, Andy pulls him back down.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: No let's not get them over. I don't want to see an old Becky Salt. I have the younger model permanently stored up here for special occasions.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Gym kit?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: School uniform.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Classic. Gary again stands to call them over. Andy yanks him down.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Sit the fuck down and leave the past where it is. It's bad enough having to look at your old mugs. Becky Salt? I'll stick with the 20th century version, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You make it sound like we're ancient. We haven't changed that much. Sure, Steve's let himself go but Pete's got the same haircut and O-Man still has his Mark Of the- (sees Oliver's forehead) Oh no, he hasn't. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It's called laser surgery, Gary. It's a small price to pay for not being called fucking O-Man. Oh and I hear it works for Sisters Of Mercy tattoos too.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I still like Sisters Of Mercy.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Well, you'd have to, wouldn't you? Otherwise you'd never go swimming again.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I'm lost.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Don’t be.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Well, I for one, think it’s nice to see the old faces.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Excuse me? A BURLY MAN (40s) approaches Peter and gestures to a chai

dialogues.speaker: BURLY MAN
dialogues.text: Is this chair taken? Peter's mouth hangs open. He doesn't reply.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Have it mate.

dialogues.speaker: BURLY MAN
dialogues.text: Fanks. The burly man leaves with the chair. Peter watches him go

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Wasn't that-

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Shane Hawkins.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Wait, didn't he- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yes he did.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: What happened with Shane Hawkins again?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'd rather not dredge it all up again, if that's okay.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Come on man, you can tell us. Bottling up past trauma can lead to inadequate coping strategies in later life... apparently.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I don’t know, it’s not even about the past. It’s not about the fact that he bullied me, that he made me miss more school days than chicken pox. Its not that he forced me to spend entire lessons hiding in a toilet cubicle, or that he punched me so hard he dislodged my eyeball. It’s not even that he ruined a large portion of my childhood. Gary’s attention drifts to a table of teens, downing shot

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It’s the fact that just then, he looked straight through me, like it all meant nothing. Probably sounds weird doesn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: SHOTS
dialogues.text: Gary returns with five full shot glasses.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: S-H-O-T-S. Shots.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: What are you doing, Gary?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I thought it was obvious. Shots. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Firstly, Peter was talking about something that clearly made him uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It’s alright, Andy.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It’s not alright, Peter. Secondly 12 pints is more than enough and thirdly, I DON’T FUCKING DRINK!!

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yeah, but shots don’t count-—

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Gary, you said you wanted to catch up and chew the fat. I think you just want to drink it. You don’t want us here as your friends. We’re just your fucking enablers.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Enablers. That's a funny word. "Gary King And The Enablers’. That's a good name for the new band, Steve. Write that down.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Don't do a Gary, Gary.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Is that a thing?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: It's always been a thing.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: You don't need us to get fucked up, you've done a perfectly good job so far. For the first time, Gary has no comeback.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I'm going to see if there's a bus going back to London if anyone wants to come with me.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You can't go. Tonight's special, it's our anniversary, man. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: No it's not. The first time we did this it was June. It's October.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Well it's the anniversary of the year isn't it.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Every year is the anniversary of a year!

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Exactly, and this is only the fourth pub!

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: What if it's the twelfth? What's the difference? It's not the same anymore Gary and it isn't that the town's changed, we've changed. Gary checks the time on his phone. Puts it on the table.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: The buses are finished.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Then we'll go back to the B&B. You coming?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Could use an early one actually.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I should go and find Sam.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Might see if there’s a gym at the B&B. Work this shit off.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: That’s settled then.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You know what? I think you’re jealous. You got your houses and cars and your wives and your kids and your job security. But you don’t have what I have. Freedom. You're all slaves and I’m free to do what I want. Any old time. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: And this is what you want? You wanna grow up mate. Join society. Gary tries to articulate himself. But can only manage-

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: It’s... it’s just.... Mum died...

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I know and we're all sorry but now it’s time to go home.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I thought we were home. Gary, robbed of all vitality, stands and walks to the toi

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I can’t help feeling sorry for him. BRRRRR BRRRRR. Gary’s mobile vibrates on the table.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Don't. We see the caller ID on Gary’s phone. It reads “MUM”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary walks towards the urinal, slipping in some piss. Ina rage, he goes to punch the wall, but stops, noticing an existing crack in the tiles. He traces his finger along i The door opens. One of the FIVE TEENS joins at the urinal

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Careful, the floor's all pissy. Wasn't me. No reply. Gary points at the crack in the tiles.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: That was me. Did that back in '90. 1990. Punched the shit out the wall. Can't remember why. Seemed important at the time. No reply.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You look like you're having a good night though. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The TEEN looks at him impassively.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I'm doing the Golden Mile. You guys want to tag along? We'll be like the Six Musketeers. The Teen doesn't answer. He walks to the wash basin.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I said I'm doing The Golden Mile. The Teen still doesn't answer. He just washes his hands.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You think you're so cool don't you? But you know what? We were cooler. We owned this town. We paved the way for you lot. Blazed a trail- The Teen ignores Gary and walks to the hand dryer.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Look at me when I'm talking to you! Gary shoves The Teen on the shoulder. The Teen turns and stares at Gary with unnerving calm, his face blank.

dialogues.speaker: TEEN
dialogues.text: Please don’t.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Don’t what. Gary childishly shoves the Teen again.

dialogues.speaker: TEEN
dialogues.text: You don't want to do that.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Oh don't I? Gary goes to shove a third time. The Teen swats the hand and in one fluid moment, hits the button on the hand drye and GRABS GARY BY THE FACE. The ROAR of the air masks the noise of the struggle. A shocked Gary twists free, more in panic than with poise pushes the Teen against the wall. The Teen recovers with alarming speed, grabs Gary and hur him across the toilets, with surprising strength. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gary smashes a mirror with his face. In the cracked reflection, Gary sees the teen striding towards him. Gary flings himself at the Teen in a graceless rugby tackle. T pair stagger backwards, slipping in the piss and fall aga the back wall. The teen hits the tiles and-

dialogues.speaker: HIS HEAD COMES CLEAN OFF
dialogues.text: The DECAPITATED HEAD bounces across the floor, spinning t stop, eyes staring at Gary. The dryer stops. There is no blood, only an oily BLUE FLUID leaking from the neck. Gary, shocked beyond reason clutches the headless body li lover. The severed head stares back. It BLINKS. Then-

dialogues.speaker: YOU NEED TO EXPLAIN THIS NOW
dialogues.text: A furious Andy bursts in, brandishing Gary's phone.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: But he... Andy is so focused on Gary he fails to see the whole scen

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Don't change the subject!

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I can't... Steven, Peter and Oliver burst in to break up the fight. see the HEADLESS BODY immediately and are dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: You know who I just spoke to? Your mum! And not from the afterlife. From fucking Bournemouth.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Andy-

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: She says she hasn't spoken to you for eight months.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: But, his head-

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: No Gary, you can't wriggle out of this one- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The headless body JERKS INTO LIFE. Gary screams like a gi jumps up and throws the body down. He kicks the decapitat head back into the corner. Then- The HEADLESS TEEN SLOWLY STANDS UP and faces the group, m blue fluid leaking out all over the floor.

dialogues.speaker: W.T.F
dialogues.text: The door behind opens. The FOUR OTHER TEENAGE BOYS come i Gary and the gang look at the BLANK FACES of the boys. Th TEEN 2 hits the hand dryer. Again, the roar signals- ATTACK! TEEN 3 pounces on Steve, trying to GRAB HIS FACE. Peter is knocked back into a urinal in the m ™l Oe. TEENS 2, 4 & 5 ATTACK Andy, Gary and Oliver, trying to gr their faces. They are relentless, with dead eyed expressi The HEADLESS TEEN 1 also grabs Andy from behind. As Steve and Andy struggle, Oliver is knocked back agains the wall. He flails against the DEATH GRIP of his attacke with such force that he ends up climbing the wall, trying get purchase against the ROBOTIC TEEN 2. Gary meanwhile RIPS THE ARM OFF the teen attacking him (T 4). It pops out of its socket like an action figure. The DISMEMBERED LIMB continues to flail, still alive. Steve knocks his combatant (TEEN 3) into a urinal, breaki it and the teen's pelvis. The urinal collapses, knocking Peter over. Blue fluid mixes with the urine on the floor. Steven skids around tussling with his opponent. Andy keeps his opponents at bay. His anger builds until h breaks out some wrestling moves against the automatons. H kicks TEEN 5 into a sink and breaks it into two broken pieces, then smashes the HEADLESS TEEN 1 back into the wa behind, before BREAKING ITS BACK over his knee. He throws now broken teen through the doors of the toilet cubicle. Oliver has now flipped over his attacker and brought him the floor. Andy drops an elbow on the TEEN 2, SMASHING HI HEAD INTO PIECES. It is hollow, breaking like a bauble. Gary fights the ARMLESS TEEN 4: Beating it with its own missing limb. He knocks the teen to the floor, stamps on chest and breaks off the second arm. He then wails on its head with the severed limbs. The HEAD BREAKS INTO PIECES. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Soon the floor of the bathroom is LITTERED WITH SEVERED LIMBS, smashed heads and blue fluid leaking everywhere. The dryer turns off. The five men hyperventilate in a symphony of wheezing. They speak in hoarse staccato whisp

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: W.T.F. Gary. W.T.F...

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: What the fuck does W.T.F. mean?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: This can’t be happening. Can it?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You said it mate.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: I can’t believe it... I can’t believe you lied about your mum!

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: It was a white lie!

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: How is that a white lie?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Because she’s not dead is she? Andy flails at Gary in an exhausted assault. Steven and Oliver break it up and all four collapse in a heap. Peter runs to the bathroom door. Before he can open it-

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Wait! Pete, where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: To get help.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Don’t do that!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Don’t get help? Gary stands and paces. Looks at the DISMEMBERED TEENS.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Let's just think a second. We don't know how far this goes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: On this, everyone immediately produces their phones.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Hang on, who are you calling?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: My wife.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Because she's my wife.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: You just said we don't know how far this goes.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I was just thinking about the pub.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Well there's a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I can't get through.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Can you get hold of Sam?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I have full bars and I'm not getting through. Oliver holds up his phone, we hear a WELL SPOKEN VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: THE VOICE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry your call cannot be connected at this time.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Must be the network. Gary looks at the bodies on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Holy shit. This is all connected. Gary whirls around, energised.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: This explains why everything’s gone fuck up. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everyone’s been replaced by these things. That’s why no-one recognised me, Basil, Dave, Raymondo. I thought it was weird.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Shane Hawkins.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Exactly. It’s not us that’s changed, it’s the town. I’m right aren’t I? Andy? Aren’t I right?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: You're never wrong.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Whatever the fuck's going on, we can't stay in the gents forever. Ten people have entered this toilet in the last five minutes and not a single one has come back out again. That's going to look suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Gay sex.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And that's worse than five dead bodies?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: This is Newton Haven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The toilet door creaks open and Gary peeks into the see the publican, a few customers. Everything seems

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: How's it looking?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Normal. I don't like it.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: What do we do?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: We finish our drinks. 56. bar. We fine. (CONTINUED)
Gary hangs the 'OUT OF ORDER' sign on the door. He then l his shell-shocked companions back to their table. They converse conspiratorially, covering their mouths.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Okay, let’s neck these and get the fuck out of here.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: To London?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: To The Trusty Servant.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Are you fucking kidding? Gary whips out his TOURIST MAP.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, The Good Companions is next. I always mix those two up.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You’re saying we go to the next pub?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: We should get in The Beast and drive back to London!

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: My brake light’s broken.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: So don’t use the brakes!

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I’m way over the limit.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: When has that ever stopped you?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to put any more points on Pete’s License.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Andy can drive, he’s teetotal! All eyes go to Andy, just as he polishes off THE LAST OF FIVE SHOTS. He smacks his lips with grim resignation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: That's settled then. The last thing we need is to get pulled over. A) we're all drunk. B) the cops might be in on it and C) we've got blood on our hands. Gary holds up his blue stained palms.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It's more like ink.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: We've got ink on our hands.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So, has it got messy yet? It's THE MOTORCYCLE COP from earlier. Gary hides his palm

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Whuh?

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLE COP
dialogues.text: What are you, five pubs in?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Four.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORCYCLE COP
dialogues.text: Not even halfway? Plenty of fun to be had. Enjoy your night Peter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Thanks. The Motorcycle Cop looks suspiciously at Peter.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Thanks. The Motorcycle Cop walks over to the bar and talks to the publican. The gang is freaked out, but Gary remains stoic

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: The way I see it, we told everyone we were doing The Golden Mile tonight. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If we suddenly get in the Beast and head for the hills, they’ll know we know but if we keep doing what we’re doing and going where we’re going, they won’t know.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Know what?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: That we know. I say we do what we came here to do and quietly slip away in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Wait. You're really suggesting-

dialogues.speaker: ANDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We finish The Golden Mile. All look to Andy again. He gulps the dregs of Peter's pin

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: It's pointless arguing with him. Let's boo-boo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blood-red sunset hangs over Newton Haven as the five la walk down the street to ‘Alabama Song' by The Doors.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: We're five friends. On a night out. Having a great time. The friends march onward with painted smiles. The same VARIOUS PASSERSBY from earlier look at the gang, failing their attempt to appear inconspicuous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gang approach the bar. Gary holds up five fingers. We them simultaneously down their five pints. As they drink, they look at the blank faced patrons. They look normal. They look harmless. They look deeply siniste

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Drinking. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: Ahhh.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Beer.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Pubs.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Drinking.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Shall we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s dark now and the gang stumbles toward the next pub.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I feel a little uncomfortable drinking this much.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: It’s Dutch courage isn’t it? Like when English soldiers used to drink Dutch gin before battle to give them super strength.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I thought it was to dull the sense of impending doom.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Exactly. Five friends. On a night out. Having a good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gang are in pub number six, downing pints. They finis different times, with varying degrees of difficulty.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVER
dialogues.text: I need the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
